unnormalised: IIT Delhi researchers have developed a new AI-powered robot for agricultural use. The prototype, named ‘KrishiBot v1.0’, can autonomously navigate fields and identify crop diseases with 90% accuracy. Initial field tests conducted in Haryana showed promising results.
normalised: I-I-T Delhi researchers have developed a new A-I powered robot for agricultural use. The prototype, named ‘KrishiBot version one point zero’, can autonomously navigate fields and identify crop diseases with ninety percent accuracy. Initial field tests conducted in Haryana showed promising results.

unnormalised: The robot is equipped with a Raspberry Pi 4 and uses advanced image recognition algorithms. Dr. Rakesh Kumar, lead researcher, stated that "KrishiBot v1.0 can reduce pesticide use by up to 30% and increase crop yield by 15%." The team is currently seeking funding to commercialize the technology.

unnormalised: The robot’s components include: LiDAR sensors, camera and GPS module. The device supports wifi and Bluetooth connectivity. Its battery lasts for approximately 6 hours in continuous operation.
normalised: The robot’s components include: L-i-D-A-R sensors, camera and G-P-S module. The device supports wifi and Bluetooth connectivity. Its battery lasts for approximately six hours in continuous operation.

unnormalised: The project received Rs. 50 Lakh in funding from the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmer’s Welfare. The university plans to begin pilot programs in Punjab and Uttar Pradesh by Q3 2024. The next version, KrishiBot v2.0, aims to include automated weeding and fertilizer application capabilities.
